metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with Envisat ASAR in the A'rou foci experimental area on Jun. 19, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with Envisat ASAR was obtained in No. 1, 2 and 3 quadrates of the A'rou foci experimental area on Jun. 19, 2008. GPR observations were also carried out in one sampling strip.
     The Envisat ASAR data were in AP mode and VV/VH polarization combinations, and the overpass time was approximately at 11:17 BJT. Simultaneous with the satellite overpass, numerous ground data were collected, the soil temperature, soil volumetric moisture, the loss tangent, soil conductivity, and the real part and the imaginary part of soil complex permittivity were acquired by the POGO soil sensor, and the mean soil temperature from 0-5cm by the probe thermometer. Those provide reliable ground data for retrieval and validation of the surface temperature and evapotranspiration from remote sensing approaches.
     Four files were included, ASAR data, No. 1, 2 and 3 quadrates data.

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used for obtaining soil moisture information in the 阿柔加密观测区?
Concept Completion.Answer: Envisat ASAR, POGO portable soil moisture sensors, ground-penetrating radar

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of soil moisture data collected using portable sensors in remote sensing experiments?
Feature Specification.Answer: soil volumetric water content, soil temperature, loss tangent, soil conductivity, real and imaginary parts of soil permittivity

Quantification.Question: How many sample plots were used for Envisat ASAR soil moisture and ground-penetrating radar observations in the Aru dense observation area on June 19, 2008?

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on soil moisture estimation accuracy when utilizing multiple ground observation techniques, such as POGO sensors and ground-penetrating radar, in conjunction with Envisat ASAR data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of multiple ground observation techniques like POGO sensors and ground-penetrating radar alongside Envisat ASAR data enhances soil moisture estimation accuracy by providing comprehensive ground truth data, allowing for improved calibration and validation of remote sensing models. This multi-source approach helps capture diverse soil moisture parameters, such as volumetric water content and dielectric properties, leading to more reliable remote sensing inversion of surface temperature and evapotranspiration.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of conducting synchronous soil moisture observation and ground-penetrating radar surveys in collaboration with Envisat ASAR data collection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of conducting synchronous soil moisture observation and ground-penetrating radar surveys is to obtain detailed soil moisture information across different sample plots. This data can be used to develop and validate remote sensing algorithms for retrieving land surface temperature and evapotranspiration, providing essential ground truth data to improve the accuracy and reliability of remote sensing models.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental techniques and procedures used to collect synchronized soil moisture and ground-penetrating radar data in the context of Envisat ASAR observations for soil moisture information retrieval?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The instrumental techniques and procedures involve using POGO portable soil moisture sensors to measure soil volumetric water content, soil temperature, loss tangent, soil conductivity, and real and imaginary parts of soil dielectric constant. Additionally, pin thermometers are used to obtain the average soil temperature at 0-5cm depth. Ground-penetrating radar is employed to conduct observations along a sample transect, synchronized with Envisat ASAR data collection using the AP mode with VV/VH polarization combination at approximately 11:17 BJT.
